channel.description: Technology. Code. Living relentlessly in the real world.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: August
item.description:
A short month with only 4 filmsâ€¦

Bullet Train

#FF22 Bullet Train is a fine if somewhat forgettable entry into the overstylized action genre.

People have codenames that appear onscreen, we jump around the timeline, the dialogue is snappy: you've seen this before.

Entertaining enough action. Generally fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 7, 2022

Prey

#FF22 Prey is an excellent entry in the Predator franchise.

Beautifully shot, well-paced, tense, brutal action. Midthunder is fantastic as the lead, bringing tenacity and vulnerability to the role.

Original and exciting, while bringing back the ethos of the original.

Must see.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 7, 2022

Nope

#FF22 Nope defies neat explanations and simple categorisation.

The cast are strong and it looks great, with the main action being clear and focussed. That recurring sequence in the TV studio is superbly tense. The message is harder to extract.

Enjoyable, but not straightforward

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 20, 2022

Day Shift

#FF22 Day Shift starts with a solid, quiet action scene that sets the world up neatly...

...and quickly devolves. While the action remains decent, the plot is nonsense and most of the characters don't make sense; world-stuffing the film for a franchise.

Forgettably entertaining

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 21, 2022

The August Winner

While Nope is interesting, Prey has to be the winner: a great action film that rejuvenates a flagging franchise.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: July
item.description:
A very light and unimpressive month for July, with just three films.

Thor: Love And Thunder

#FF22 Thor: Love And Thunder is about as paint by numbers as Marvel gets.

It takes no chances, does nothing fresh. The plot and character development are woefully undercooked too: Bale is solid as Gorr, but it doesn't give him much time to build up. Some fun moments.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) July 24, 2022

Where The Crawdads Sing

#FF22 Where The Crawdads Sing is comically bad.

The dialogue and performances are close to parody territory with only Strathairn any good. The plot is as silly as it is predictable. I'm not bothered about not seeing what actually happened, because I'd long stopped caring.

Avoid

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) July 24, 2022

The Gray Man

#FF22 The Gray Man doesn't do much with its strong cast.

The plot is straight from the action-film-script generator, with action that matches, and little in the way of originality or flair anywhere. Setup, location, set-piece, over and over, with little connection.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 7, 2022

The July Winner

A pretty grim month, so Thor: Love And Thunder inexplicably wins by being the only film I might possibly watch a second time many years from now.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: June
item.description:
A fairly short Film Fight for June, with just 5 films.

Men

#FF22 Men is not a subtle film in the slightest.

It is, however, an effective small horror, with exceptionally strong performances by the two leads, and several visceral and creepy moments that will live in my memory.

A little slow towards the end, but decent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) June 12, 2022

Spiderhead

#FF22 Spiderhead takes a broad look at abuses in pharmaceuticals, focussing on issues of control like a lightweight Milgram experiment.

The cast are fine, seemingly having fun, and the runtime passes quickly, but the film doesn't have much to say in the end.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) July 3, 2022

Pleasure

#FF22 Pleasure focusses on issues of consent and power in the adult entertainment industry.

Bella's journey is not an easy watch, each step taking her further into that world. Thyberg's direction/writing is even-handed: neither celebrating or condeming it.

Good, not easy.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) July 3, 2022

Top Gun: Maverick

#FF22 Top Gun: Maverick is very much an 80s film in modern clothing.

The plot is silly and the machismo is over the top, with too many nods to the original. But it's still a lot of fun. The action sequences are predictable, but spectacular, and it all comes together.

Fun.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) July 3, 2022

Hustle

#FF22 Hustle follows a basketball scout, looking for his next break.

This is a serious Sandler film, without being dour. It pulls together several underdog and sport movie plots into something new enough. There are laughs, difficulties, and triumphs that keep it moving.

Solid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) July 3, 2022

The June Winner

A tricky one because thereâ€™s plenty of good but nothing excellent here. I think the movie Iâ€™d see again soonest is Men, so thatâ€™s the winner.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: May
item.description:
Seven films for May.

All The Old Knives

#FF22 All The Old Knives is a very solid, mid-budget, spy thriller.

It, rightly, focusses on espionage and intrigue, rather than action. The cast (Chris Pine, Thandiwe Newton) do a great job of pulling you into the drama, as the narrative threads shift around.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 7, 2022

The Contractor

#FF22 The Contractor fails to do much interesting with its premise.

The slow and uneven pace don't help with the vague stakes, and predictable plot turns. The action lacks energy; with most sequences feeling very staged. The cast can't do much.

It's not bad, it's very average.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 8, 2022

Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness

#FF22 Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness is fine, if you enjoy Marvel films.

Raimi does a great job of injecting an 80s horror vibe, with a surprising amount of violence for the rating. It's a relative tame take on the multiverse, and not one well-explored

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 15, 2022

Operation Mincemeat

#FF22 Operation Mincemeat is a historical drama focussing on espionage in WW2.

While it tells the story well enough, it doesn't go into any depth. All of the sharp edges have been sanded down, and a by-numbers romantic subplot bolted on. The cast are fine.

Decent if lightweight

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 15, 2022

Everything Everywhere All At Once

#FF22 Everything Everywhere All At Once is the kind of weird, fun sci-fi we need more of.

The cast helps the emotional weight of the story shine through, where it might have been lost to the wacky concepts. The directors are showing off with great nods to world cinema

Excellent

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 15, 2022

Jackass 4.5

#FF22 Jackass 4.5 does largely what you expect. As with the other .5 increments, it's a mix of making-of documentary and unused footage from the main film.

It's fun to see the chaotic thinking behind the scenes, but isn't going to be for everyone.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) June 12, 2022

Emergency

#FF22 Emergency plays with its tone well.

It has the setup of a college comedy, with an elaborate drinking quest but quickly it becomes something far more serious, flipping between moods.

Solid performances throughout but the fear/raw emotion in the last act is stunning.

Watch

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) June 12, 2022

The May Winner

The May winner is the unexpected brilliance of Everything Everywhere All At Once.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: April
item.description:
Only five films in this fight, but theyâ€™re mostly good.

Titane

#FF22 Titane is a strange film that deserves it's Cronenbergian nods.

A mish-mash of violence and movement makes up a movie concerned with bodies and what they should and should not do; about love, and need. Beyond flat description.

Strange.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2022

Apollo 10 1/2: A Space Age Childhood

#FF22 Apollo 10 1/2: A Space Age Childhood brings together a few Linklater tropes pleasantly.

It's an easy going look at a moment in time, with rotoscoped animation making it seem further away. The narration didn't work for me, but the plot progresses nicely enough.

Decent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 17, 2022

The Northman

#FF22 The Northman is not a subtle film.

At times mythic and supernatural, at others full of brutality grounded by those excellent one-shots. It's silly, weird, and gripping. SkarsgÃ¥rd is excellent as the ball of rage at the heart of the film.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 17, 2022

The Bubble

#FF22 The Bubble tries to have fun with its premise, but isn't fully cooked.

There are some decent, knowing jokes, but far too few for the runtime. There's not much of a plot, more of a bunch of sequences they wanted in place.

Underwritten, too long, and not much fun. Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 30, 2022

Mass

#FF22 Mass is an incredible film about loss and anger, and forgiveness.

The style subtly shifts as the mood changes but four powerhouse performances are at the centre of the film, with a single location letting the film focus on the actors.

Film of the year contender.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 1, 2022

The April Winner

While The Northman was winning until late on the last day of the month, Mass is the clear winner; a difficult film that will stay with me for years to come.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: March
item.description:
Seven films for the March Film Fight:

Wrath Of Man

#FF22 Wrath Of Man transplants Guy Ritchie's Cockney Gangster schtick to US security trucks, to disastrous effect.

The dialogue is painful: bizarre phrasing and weird delivery. The plot itself is... fine, but it feels very slow and the action sequences mostly fall flat.

Avoid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 5, 2022

Kimi

#FF22 Kimi is a perfect evening watch.

It's part techno-thriller, part Hitcockian-noir. Well-paced, with a paranoid undertone. Zoe Kravitz is excellent as the lead, and Soderbergh does his usual magic behind the camera.

Easy, fun, great.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 18, 2022

The Batman

#FF22 The Batman is a solid entry in the canon.

Set during Year 2, Pattinson plays a scrappier, but accomplished, Batman well. The supporting cast are all good, too.

It is, however, far too dark, and about an hour too long. Lots of extraneous stuff packed in.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 18, 2022

The Adam Project

#FF22 The Adam Project is mindless, big budget action with a bit of sci-fi.

Ryan Reynolds plays the same character he always does, so if you like that generally, youâ€™ll like this.

Silly plot, fun action, easy going.

Totally fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 19, 2022

After Yang

#FF22 After Yang is a slow but delicate film about loss, memory, and family.

Set in a not far-off future, we see a distant father reconnect with this family through the death of a family android.

Quiet, subtle, beautiful.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2022

Windfall

#FF22 Windfall is low budget, Netflix fodder, as a man inadvertently kidnaps a billionaire and his wife.

The cast is solid enough, but the plot is stretched a little too thin, especially over the first half. Small, simple, short. Easy enough.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2022

Death On The Nile

#FF22 Death On The Nile is teatime drama as blockbuster.

A huge cast of terrible accents, going through the old story again. It's perfectly fine at what it is, but you've seen this exact thing many times. The wide shots look terribly fake, but otherwise a pretty film.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2022

The month Winner

Lots of big, silly films but not so many great films, making it an easy win for Kimi.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: February
item.description:
A fairly decent month with 7 films in the fight.

The Eyes Of Tammy Faye

#FF22 The Eyes Of Tammy Faye is a great insight into televangelism.

Chastaine's performance is transformative; slightly odd and utterly engaging. Garfield is solid too.

The pacing is a little off, suddenly jumping forward years, but it's a riveting watch.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 15, 2022

Uncharted

#FF22 Uncharted is as by the numbers as action films get. The jokes, the plot, the double-crosses, the set pieces, the banter: done okay but you've seen everything in this film before.

The leads are miscast and struggle to gel.

Fine, if you go in with expectations suitably set.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 15, 2022

CODA

#FF22 Coda is an exceptional film: balancing many plot threads, characters, and struggles, and bringing the together at the right moment.

It looks gorgeous, with some incredibly powerful moments setup through visual and sound design. Strong performances from all.

A must-see.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 20, 2022

Petite Maman

#FF22 Petite Maman presents the slightly fantastical (a young girl meets her mother at an earlier point in her life) through a realist lens.

While there are cute moments, the flat affect and knowing dialogue break the illusion.

Doesn't say much but says what it does well.

Fine

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 20, 2022

Belfast

#FF22 Belfast reminds me of A Christmas Story: capturing family moments from a different time, but with the shadow of The Troubles looming.

It's a little sappy, but not cloyingly so. It looks incredible, and the young actor who the movie focuses on does a great job.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 20, 2022

Lamb

#FF22 Lamb is a delightful, unsettling horror about motherhood and family.

The Icelandic terrain is a stark backdrop to the uneasy new family member. Noomi Rapace is excellent throughout. While the pace dips a little, the film has enough going on to stay interesting.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 27, 2022

The Tragedy Of Macbeth

#FF22 The Tragedy Of Macbeth is an impeccably gorgeous take on the classic: every shot beautifully lit and framed.

The witches are stunningly portrayed, amongst a strong cast with only a few flat line readings.

A little cold, at times, but a fantastic ending.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 27, 2022

The February Winner

Although Chastaineâ€™s performance in Tammy Faye is excellent, the winner is CODA: great performances, stunningly shot, and bold direction; a film deserving of its Oscar nominations.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: January
item.description:
A big start to 2022, with 11 new films. A very mixed bag.

The Protege

#FF22 The Protege is a fairly forgettable action film, with two very solid leads.

Maggie Q and Michael Keaton both work well in their roles, but the story is underwritten and the wider character motivations basically unknown.

A few action sequences work well, but meh overall.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 6, 2022

The Lost Daughter

#FF22 The Lost Daughter is a fascinating tapestry of moments and memory, emotions bubbling up and those held in, barely.

Colman puts in a layered performance, always seeming moments away from a snapping point (Buckley does well here too). Well explored.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 6, 2022

Licorice Pizza

#FF22 Licorice Pizza is a bit of a shaggy dog story, capturing moments disparately of a love story with a big question mark.

Funny in moments, and fun to watch, it's more about the mood than the story, and that's fine. A great film to sit and watch, and soak in.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 6, 2022

Swan Song

#FF22 Swan Song is a Black Mirror-esque story about what it is that makes us who we were.

Avoiding the plot itself, Mahershala Ali is excellent as always, bringing depth to a difficult role. The back third needs a little trimming but it's all beautifully shot and engaging.

Good

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 6, 2022

Mother/Android

#FF22 Mother/Android is a disappointingly flat take on a robot uprising story.

The two leads are good individually but lack chemistry (and natural-sound dialogue) to help sell it. There are some tense set pieces (in the house), but it's all a bit predictable and derivative.

Meh

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 8, 2022

The Tender Bar

#FF22 The Tender Bar is what happens when the subtext becomes the text, narrated loudly and bluntly stated.

There's no reason to care about the lead, a relatively quiet and charmless boy; his lack of goals; or to want his cliche-mandated conclusion.

Obvious, and dull.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 23, 2022

Preparations To Be Together For An Unknown Period Of Time

#FF22 Preparations To Be Together For An Unknown Period Of Time seems like it'll delve into a delusional cliche, but instead doesn't really do anything.

A tentative love story, creeps forward slowly, and lands... somewhere.

Fine, if unexciting.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 23, 2022

The Starling

#FF22 The Starling is a clunky movie, full of heavy-handed symbolism.

A solid cast is entirely wasted on scene after scene of disconnected drama, with only the CGI titular character coming away as having done its job.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 23, 2022

Nightmare Alley

#FF22 Nightmare Alley left me feeling... indifferent.

It held my interest for the run time, but so much seemed obvious: from the tealy-orange grading, through other visual choices. The twist and the ending were entirely predictable, but seemed held up as big surprises.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 23, 2022

A Journal For Jordan

#FF22 A Journal For Jordan is the slow but surprisingly sweet tale of unexpected and ultimately doomed love.

The end is very cheesey, but the rest works remarkably well. The two leads give solid performances, and have clear chemistry.

Watchable.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 15, 2022

Friends And Strangers

#FF22 Friends And Strangers fails to engage much.

Intentionally meandering and largely plotless, it has moments of conversation that are interesting and then discarded. A scene at a rich family's home approaches unsettling horror... and stops.

Unsatisfying and languid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 15, 2022

The January Winner

While Licorice Pizza is an excellent slice of life film, I think The Lost Daughter is the monthly winner. Several very strong performances, a compelling story, beautifully shot.

item.title: Film Fight 2021: Finale
item.description:
Wow, another year of mostly at home viewing, but with a bit more cinema thrown in, particularly towards the end. Itâ€™s been a decent enough year for film, with maybe a few too many big-budget action films dominating screens in the back end of the year (looking at you Marvel!).

As per the caveat every year, Film Fight is done in a (non particularly serious) knock-out style: it can pick my favourite film of the year, but nothing else. (Also the very idea of a single favourite film is a bit silly.)

First up is the honorable mentions: films that werenâ€™t good enough to win their own month, but still worth seeing.

  • Saint Frances
  • Pieces Of A Woman
  • Soul
  • Ham On Rye
  • One Night In Miami
  • Malcolm & Marie
  • I Care A Lot
  • Moxie
  • Barb & Star Go To Vista Del Mar
  • Dead Pigs
  • Bacurau
  • Concrete Cowboy
  • Proxima
  • The Mauritanian
  • Cherry
  • Sound Of Metal
  • The Woman In The Window
  • Shirley
  • Oxygen
  • Shiva Baby
  • Mogul Mowgli
  • Minari
  • Body Brokers
  • First Cow
  • The Best Of Enemies
  • Black Bear
  • New Order
  • Another Round
  • The Nest
  • Worth
  • Kate
  • Sweat
  • The Guilty
  • The Last Duel
  • Cop Shop
  • The French Dispatch
  • The Trouble With Being Born
  • Surge
  • In The Earth
  • Spider-Man: No Way Home
  • Donâ€™t Look Up
  • Azor
  • Being The Ricardos
  • Encounter

And now the monthly winners:

  • January: Babyteeth
  • February: Possessor
  • March: Judas & The Black Messiah
  • April: Promising Young Woman
  • May: Nomadland
  • June: The Father
  • July: Clemency
  • August: The Green Knight
  • September: Apples
  • October: Last Night In Soho
  • November: The Harder They Fall
  • December: The Power Of The Dog

Thatâ€™s as solid a list of winners as any other year, and genuinely difficult to narrow it down to just one.

The body-horror of Possessor has stayed with me through the year; the sign of an excellent, creepy movie. Meanwhile, The Green Knight has this beautiful, mythic feel that makes me want to watch it again.

Difficult movies abounded: Clemency, The Father, and Babyteeth are not films Iâ€™ll be revisiting soon, but only because they were hard enough to watch the first time.

Nomadland and The Harder They Fall were both beautifully styled, with very different aesthetics: naturalism vs hyper-stylised.

The real challenge, though, is picking between Promising Young Woman and The Power Of The Dog. Each are excellent in their own ways, playing with our expectations expertly. I donâ€™t want to say much about the content of either, because you should watch them without knowing whatâ€™s coming.

I think Iâ€™m going to go with Promising Young Woman: darkly funny, tragic, brutal, tense, well-paced, with several great performances. A must see.

item.title: Film Fight 2021: December
item.description:
The December Film Fight ended up being a big one: 12 films in all.

Surge

#FF21 Surge isn't what I expected and you should go in largely blind.

Ben Wishaw is great, both frightening and vulnerable as the situation continues. That's enhanced by the discordant audio, and tight camera angles that make the film claustrophobic.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 11, 2021

The Power of The Dog

#FF21 The Power of The Dog is an excellent, compelling film.

Strong performances from all of the leads mix with beautiful visuals.

The script is the real winner, though: lots of little turns that were signposted, in retrospect. Will reward a repeat viewing.

Excellent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 11, 2021

Infinite

#FF21 Infinite was worth than I expected, and my bar was set very low.

Poorly shot action, bad acting and dialogue, and a silly plot that doesn't hold up its own premise particularly well; a "clever" concept that never delivers on anything it sets up.

Avoid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 11, 2021

In The Earth

#FF21 In The Earth takes Ben Wheatley back to quiet, creeping, horror.

The small cast, remote location, and weird moments give the whole thing an otherworldly feel.

There are a few moments that are a little cliched, but an enjoyable and uncomfortable watch overall.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 11, 2021

The Card Counter

#FF21 The Card Counter left me colder than it intends.

Despite a solid cast, the performances don't work: a flat affect as disjointed dialogue is delivered without care, to a disconnected soundtrack. The threads of the story don't cohere, and nothing satisfies.

Bad and boring.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 11, 2021

Spider-Man: No Way Home

#FF21 Spider-Man: No Way Home is a good Marvel film in its own right and a nice cap on an ongoing story.

While it can be self-indulgent, the nods and winks to the past generally work well. The plot is a little overstuffed and the editing a bit loose, but it works.

Enjoyable!

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 20, 2021

The Matrix Resurrections

#FF21 The Matrix Resurrections is so much worse than the sequels.

Barely a plot, slapped together with bad dialogue, uninteresting action, poor acting (Moss excluded), uninspired visuals, a wonky conceit, and pointless callbacks and characters, strung out for too long.

Terrible

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 1, 2022

Donâ€™t Look Up

#FF21 Don't Look Up is a fine, but broad, piece of satire.

It lacks any sort of subtlety but is an infuriatingly accurate take on how the world handles crisis. A strong cast, and snappy pacing, make this a pleasant viewing experience.

Watch.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 1, 2022

Azor

#FF21 Azor is a study in disaffected politeness covering up societal evils.

Following a Swiss banker during the Argentinean regime change, as he goes on social visits to politely discuss a number of concerning issues without discussing them. Beautifully shot and told.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 1, 2022

Seven Stages of Achieving Eternal Bliss

#FF21 Seven Stages of Achieving Eternal Bliss has a good premise: a weird cult wanting to kill themselves in a couple's bath tub.

Heavy handed progression, and uneven performances, detract from what could've been a solid comedy.

Pretty forgettable.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 1, 2022

Being The Ricardos

#FF21 Being The Ricardos is a fascinating look at Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz.

It's clearly a Sorkin film: the "one vital week" structure, studded with flashbacks, a great cast delivering snappy dialogue, and solid visuals. A fun drama. A serious comedy.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 1, 2022

Encounter

#FF21 Encounter is a disturbing, skin-crawling look at losing your sense of self.

Riz Ahmed is excellent, but it's the shot choices and editing that bring out the creeping tension of the unseen threat. You'll see where it's going quickly, but that scarcely matters.

Great.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 1, 2022

The December Winner

With some very strong contenders, this should have been a tough choice but The Power Of The Dog is a clear winner for me. Itâ€™s a must-see film that you should go into blind.
